slides.title: Configuring the Add and Remove
slides.ocrText:
Configuring the Add and Remove
buttons

slides.title: I Iterator Buttons widget
slides.originalNotes:
Iterator Buttons widget
The buttons already have the appropriate visibility and availability logic:

Both buttons are visible only if the screen is edit mode

Both buttons are available only if their actions are Defined

Remove button is available only if its actions is defined AND at least one row is selected in the List View
slides.notes:
Iterator Buttons widget
The buttons already have the appropriate visibility and availability logic:

Both buttons are visible only if the screen is edit mode

Both buttons are available only if their actions are Defined

Remove button is available only if its actions is defined AND at least one row is selected in the List View
slides.ocrText:
I Iterator Buttons widget

• Iterator Buttons widget contains two buttons: Add and Remove

• It provides functionality

* To add new rows with the Add iterator button

* To remove existing rows with the Remove iterator button

• The buttons already have the appropriate visibility and availability logic

slides.title: I Toolbars
slides.originalNotes:
Toolbars
Because the PCF architecture is hierarchical in nature, there is often more than one place that a toolbar could go. In the slide example, toolbars are visible at both the screen level and list view panel container level. Besides the screen level toolbar for edit buttons, the best place for a toolbar is the highest place in the hierarchy of containers that you want the toolbar to affect. For example, if you need the same toolbar on every card of a card view, then you will provide users with a more intuitive interface if you place a single toolbar at or above the card view level as opposed to putting individual toolbars on every card
slides.notes:
Toolbars

For example, if you need the same toolbar on every card of a card view, then you will provide users with a more intuitive interface if you place a single toolbar at or above the card view level as opposed to putting individual toolbars on every card
slides.ocrText:
I Toolbars Gi

* There is more than one place that a toolbar could go
• Best place for Edit Buttons is the screen level toolbar
* Edit Buttons control the screen transaction
• Best place for Iterator Buttons is the toolbar closest to the List View
* This is typically the toolbar associated with the List View to display the paginator
* Depending on the complexity of the screen there could be only one toolbar containing both

slides.title: I Iterator buttons and row iterators
slides.originalNotes:
Iterator buttons and row iterators
The add button is usually configured one of the following two ways:

a) When the user clicks Add, a new empty row (object) is inserted in the List View. The user can initialize the row (object) by simply editing the cells.

b) When the user clicks Add, a popup opens. The popup creates an empty object and displays all the fields of the object. The user can initialize the object by specifying the different fields in the popup. When the user clicks 0K, the initialized object will beinserted to the List View and displayed as a row.

The first one is typically used when the List View displays all the fields that need to be initialized. The second approach is used when the List View displays only a few important fields of the object, but the object has more fields that need to be initialized during creation. In the example, the List View displays 3 fields of the Vendor Evaluation, but the object has other fields that may need to be initialized, so going with the second approach seems to be the better solution in this case.

Note: To implement this second use caser you would also need to configure a creational popup. Creating objects with popups is out of scope for this course.
slides.notes:

slides.ocrText:
I Iterator buttons and row iterators Gi

Typical configuration

• The typical method for the Add button is shown here, which is used when the List
View displays all the fields that need to be initialized
• The user clicks the Update button, which puts the screen in edit mode

• The user clicks the Add button, and a new empty row is inserted in the List View.
The user can initialize the row by simply editing the cells.

slides.title: Editable hierarchy
slides.originalNotes:
Editable hierarchy
The following summarizes the default value of the editable property for each element:

A list view panel's editable property is blank. The property is not required. (A list view panel with no specified editable property is editable.)

A row iterator's editable property is blank, but this property is required. To have editable cells, it must be set to true, orto a condition that evaluates to true.

A roWs editable property is blank. The property is not required. (A row with no specified editable property is editable.)

A cell's editable property is false. To have the cell be editable, you must set the property to true, or to a condition that evaluates to true.

In practice, the two elements you must explicitly set to editable to get editable cells are the row iterator and the cells that are to be made editable.
slides.notes:
Editable hierarchy

A cell's editable property is false. To have the cell be editable, you must set the property to true, or to a condition that evaluates to true.

In practice, the two elements you must explicitly set to editable to get editable cells are the row iterator and the cells that are to be made editable.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
_- — For a cell to be editable, the cell’s Editable property must be set to true.
Y What other elements, if any, must also be editable to make the cell
editable in the user interface?
SS eee ese ees SeeseseS
Gi

questionData.question: For a cell to be editable, the cell’s Editable property must be set to true. What other elements, if any, must also be editable to make the cell editable in the user interface?
questionData.answer: The List View Panel’s Row Iterator Editable property must be set to true.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
_- — For a cell to be editable, the cell’s Editable property must be set to true.
Y What other elements, if any, must also be editable to make the cell
editable in the user interface?
The List View Panel’s Row Iterator Editable property must be set to true.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Assume that an object called
Y anABContact has an Addresses array
and an Addresses list view panel whose
Row lterator is configured as shown.
Identify the errors in how the property is
configured.
SS eee ese ees SeeseseS

questionData.question: Assume that an object called anABContact has an Addresses array and an Addresses list view panel whose Row Iterator is configured as shown. Identify the errors in how the property is configured.
questionData.answer:
There are four errors:
1. The object is anABContact, not ABContact.
2. The method name starts with "addTo...", not "toAdd...".
3. The name of the array is missing from the end of the method name. (The method should be addToAddresses.)
4. The argument must reference the row iterator's element name, which is currentAddress.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
Assume that an object called
Y anABContact has an Addresses array
and an Addresses list view panel whose
Row lterator is configured as shown.
Identify the errors in how the property is
configured.
There are four errors:
1. The object is anABContact, not ABContact.
2. The method name starts with "addTo...", not "toAdd...".
3. The name of the array is missing from the end of the method name. (The method should
be addToAddresses.)
4. The argument must reference the row iterator's element name, which is currentAddress.
